summary.title: Water Generation
content: This region has one of the highest average annual relative humidity percentage matching or exceeding 75%. Atmospheric water generation is a great choice.
This region shares a descent average annual precipitation rate. Rainwater cache is a good choice for this region.
It is always recommended to tap into aquifers for a steady, consistent supply of water through water wells.

Utility water is expensive, and the majority of your region meets the national average. Only if there is no stable source of water and costs are high should this method be considered. This region might not justify the costs for alternative water generation practices based on the low cost of water.

Desalination (wastewater or saltwater) is an expensive technology. It is recommended if it fits within your budget. If you have aquifer access and mineral rights, this is not needed. If you do not have aquifer access or mineral rights, desalination might need consideration.

The temperature of this region is relatively low. If you heavily rely on Air Conditioning for cooling, Condensate Drain (CD) techniques may apply. Considering Geothermal is a preferred renewable energy source for this region, CD serves well for generating electricity, not water.

summary.title: Renewable Energy
content: Geothermal heating and cooling techniques are the best choices for this region.

Utilizing the currents from streams and tidal currents from large water bodies seems like a viable solution for power needs. As of now, we have no method to calculate specific power potential for hydro techniques.

Coastal communities share low wind speeds (within 4 – 7 mph avg.) over inland communities (4.5 – 5 mph avg.). The best wind speeds are shown near the Canadian border, with speeds reaching near 7 mph avg. Wind is not a good option for most of the region.
The peak sun hours are estimated to be 4.2 hours throughout the region. Solar is not a good option.

summary.title: Water Generation
content: The majority of this region shares a relatively high average annual precipitation rate. Rainwater cache is a great choice for most of this region. Eastern portions of Oklahoma and Texas should consider other methods to generate water.

The temperature of this region is relatively high. If you heavily rely on Air Conditioning for cooling, Condensate Drain (CD) techniques may apply. Considering Geothermal is not a preferred renewable energy source for this region, CD serves well for generating water, not electricity.

The majority of the region has one of the highest average annual relative humidity percentages that matches or exceeds 75%. Atmospheric water generation is a great choice. Areas furthest east of Texas and Oklahoma read a low percentage of annual relative humidity between 25% to 60%. These areas should not consider atmospheric water as a choice.

It is always recommended to tap into aquifers for a steady, consistent supply of water through water wells. If incorporation rainwater or atmospheric water generation, well water is strongly advised and comes highly recommended for eastern portions of this region.
